video.title: Citizen Sleeper 2: Starward Vector | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
I see all you young people out there on the 
streets pausing between kickflips to suck on your

Capri-Suns and say, &quot;Man, we&#39;re so bored by our 
flashy, new-fangled video games; there&#39;s so many

graphical bells and whistles on our mind-numbing, 
repetitive loot box delivery engines, we can

barely get our heads together long enough to smoke 
drugs.&quot; To which I say, &quot;Hey there, kid, you ever

consider playing a mostly text-based game?&quot; &quot;What? 
Text? Like what they have in school books? I&#39;m

not down with that shizzle, daddy-o; get out 
of the basketball court.&quot; &quot;Hold your horses,

young person. What if I were to tell you that 
this particular mostly text-based game is about

being a robot in space?&quot; &quot;Wow, no way, blood, 
I thought mostly text-based games were lame,

but robots in space are on fire. You&#39;re pretty 
cool for an old-timer; we&#39;ve learned the error of

our ways and will go straight to our local library 
on fleek. Or whatever that means.&quot; The mostly

text-based game in question is Citizen Sleeper 2, 
a narrative adventure game where most of the time,

the right half of the screen is a description of 
you doing something boring, and the left side of

the screen is the exterior wall of a spaceship 
in which, we are assured, the boring activity

is taking place. It&#39;s also one of the most deeply 
emotionally affecting interactive narratives I&#39;ve

played in who knows how long. And you can stick 
that right up your credit card slot, AAA games.

The premise is you are a robot in space. A 
sleeper, an artificial humanoid piloted by

an emulated consciousness copy-pasted from a 
real person because good old-fashioned regular

slavery wasn&#39;t getting the corporations&#39; dicks 
as wet as it used to, and we&#39;re in a space-going

future where humanity consists of an extremely 
loosely connected network of colonies and space

stations smeared across the galaxy like so much 
cocaine-infused snot around the mouth of John

Belushi, where corporate dystopia has sparked so 
many apocalypses, all anyone does all day now is

pick through the ancient ruins of the last 
12 corporate dystopias, looking for ancient

valuable TPS reports to flog to whoever&#39;s trying 
to create the next one. While the first game took

place entirely on a single space station, Bitcoin 
Beeper 2 increases the scope to an entire star

system as we jet-set around multiple colonies 
on a clapped-out rust bucket doing just enough

odd jobs to be able to afford sandwiches for our 
ragtag crew of misfits as we hum the Cowboy Bebop

theme tune and try to stay one step ahead of our 
evil former master who thinks he&#39;s entitled to

enslave us just because we happen to be a robot 
slave, which smacks of profiling, if you ask me.

So we&#39;re in a vaguely Disco Elysium 
sort of area that&#39;s at the midpoint

between narrative tabletop roleplaying and 
reading a choose-your-own-adventure book,

except unlike Disco Elysium, you&#39;re not 
staring down the receding hairline of a

substance-wracked car crash on legs, and instead 
of rolling each skill check as they come up,

there&#39;s a rather interesting system wherein we 
roll five dice at the start of each in-game day

and then choose which of the day&#39;s activities 
we wish to apply them to. So we might want to

really bring our A-game to an important quest 
objective and use up our five and our six there,

but then we could use some extra cash, but it&#39;s 
not that urgent, so we use our ones and twos to

phone in a shift washing dishes or at the phone 
sex hotline. It rather effectively gamifies the

very human condition of not always giving 
that much of a shit about what you&#39;re doing,

and I really relate to that. Yeah, sometimes 
I, too, have trouble focusing on a task for

reasons largely out of my control, like my 
usual mysterious mid-morning stiffy. And

I&#39;m at the age where I might sometimes roll a 
whole day of ones and twos &#39;cause I don&#39;t get

enough exercise and I fucked my back up yesterday 
afternoon because I walked across the room wrong.

Your rolls are mostly applied to skill checks 
with additions and deductions based on your stats,

and I remember complaining in Citizen Sleeper 1 
that it&#39;s too generous with the level-ups, and by

the end, you can basically be good at everything, 
which rather undermines the role playing for the

same reason one wonders why the Justice League 
wants anyone other than Superman to bother to

show up for work, and that criticism seems to have 
been taken on board, as now, all three playable

classes have one stat just completely locked out. 
I was playing as the Engineer, and that caused the

stat approximating to sociability and charisma 
to be permanently set to zero. And it doesn&#39;t

get more apt than that without also giving me a 
dexterity penalty for having Cheeto dust all over

my fingers. But in the end, it made no difference 
&#39;cause every situation has at least two approaches

you can take; I&#39;d just make up for my lack of 
social skills by fixing everyone&#39;s laptops for

them and by the end was once again overpowered and 
never facing a single skill check without massive

advantage. The game also gave me this upgradeable 
dice reroll power to try and tempt me away from

spending all my level-ups on stat improvements, 
but it only applied to specific kinds of missions,

so I didn&#39;t see the point. I&#39;d rather 
increase a general Sexual Prowess stat

than highly specifically improve my ability 
to tweak nipples on alternative Thursdays.

It&#39;s the writing that sells Citizen Sleeper; it&#39;s 
about finding the humanity in individuals caught

in hopeless conditions, and there&#39;s a focus 
on developing characters that are articulate,

well-established, and diverse, even if it&#39;s 
weird how keen they all are to make friends

with an omnicompetent espresso machine on legs. 
Maybe not that weird, on reflection. Then again,

there were times when the story lost me. 
The dramatic climax of the plot features our

character assisting in a violent revolution, but I 
found it hard to get invested &#39;cause our personal

contribution was basically sitting in a basement, 
running admin, and making sure all the Chinese

takeaways were ordered for the victory party. I 
don&#39;t think this format works very well for grand,

epic, world-changing narratives as opposed to 
interactions between individuals; it&#39;s hard to

appreciate the impact we&#39;re having on the lives 
of a nebulous population that we can&#39;t show you,

but they&#39;re all behind that wall there, and 
they all think you&#39;re super cool. But I stuck

with it &#39;cause the main reason I fondly remember 
Citizen Sleeper 1 is because the ending was good

and tied the whole experience together. In fact, 
I struggle to remember anything else about it,

frankly. And sure enough, the same is 
Citizen Sleeper true of Citizen Sleeper

2. And I need to talk about it, so here&#39;s 
a spoiler warning. SPOILER WARNING. SPOILER

WARNING. GONNA SPOIL THE PLOT. SPOILER WARNING. 
SPOILER WARNING. LEAVE IF YOU&#39;D RATHER I NOT.

Aiding the revolution and defeating your 
old master isn&#39;t the end. Afterwards,

you go right back to your life of running errands 
and feeding the cat, but now, something&#39;s wrong.

Your body is losing function. More and more of 
your dice permanently break as you pass time,

leaving you unable to complete the tasks you used 
to be so competent at. The only way to fix it and

properly end the game is to volunteer for a 
rebooting that has a decent chance of erasing

your personality. And suddenly, this game 
about finding a way to live becomes a game

about getting ready to die. About living with a 
slow decline into inevitability, of going around

completing petty side quests, knowing that with 
each success, you&#39;re ticking off another thing

you&#39;ll never do again. And speaking as someone who 
used to be able to put their leg behind their head

and who now gets a new permanent ache every time 
they stand up too quick, this resonated pretty

hard. Has the ending of a game ever made you get 
up and just stare out of a window for 10 minutes?

This one did. I think of the optimism of my youth, 
and my pessimism for a future that seems to be

spiraling into chaos in ways I am powerless to 
slow. I look at my children and the world I will

one day leave them to deal with in my absence. I 
pick up my youngest, knowing that a day will come

when I do this without realizing it&#39;s the last 
time I ever do it. And I hold her in my arms.
Okay, I&#39;ma put you down, my back hurts.
